required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Collagenase on Healing and Scarring
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Double-blind, Paired-Comparison of the Effect of Collagenase Santyl® Ointment on Healing and Scarring Characteristics of 600μm Dermatome Wounds

brief_summary.textblock: A study to compare the rate of complete wound closure and quality of resulting scar at 3, 6 and 9 months, between dermatome-induced skin wounds treated with Collagenase Santyl Ointment versus vehicle alone.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Time to Complete Wound Closure Collagenase Santyl and Vehicle

secondary_outcome.measure: Differences in Scar Viscoelasticity Between Wounds Treated With Collagenase Santyl and Its Vehicle
secondary_outcome.description: Differences in Scar Viscoelasticity between wounds treated with Collagenase Santyl and its vehicle as measured by Stiffness and Energy Absorption using BTC-2000 measurements.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Collagenase Santyl Rate of Wound Closure
arm_group.description: Dermatome-induced skin wounds treated with drug active (collagenase).
Dermatome-induced skin wounds treated with Vehicle alone.

intervention.description: Dermatome-induced skin wounds treated with drug active. Each subject serves as his own control receiving both treatments in parallel.
intervention.arm_group_label: Collagenase Santyl Rate of Wound Closure

intervention.description: Dermatome-induced skin wounds treated with Vehicle alone. Each subject serves as his own control receiving both treatments in parallel.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Provide written informed consent
2. Willing to attend all required study visits
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Known hypersensitivity to Clostridial collagenase
2. Anticoagulants (blood thinners, including aspirin) within two weeks
3. Congenital skin disorder which affects keratinocytes, elastin, or collagen
4. Any dermatologic disease which may be aggravated or provoked by the wounding procedure
5. Dark skin pigmentation to a degree which is very likely to obscure the assessment of vascularization post-wounding
6. At risk of keloid or hypertrophic scar formation
7. Scars, tattoos or deformities (i.e., contractures) on the inner aspect of the upper arm area where the wound will be placed
8. Any skin disorder which causes delayed healing
9. Disrupted lymphatic drainage of the arm to be studied, or previously diagnosed thoracic outlet syndrome
10. Taking concomitant medications at doses which are known to interfere with healing, such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, anti-neoplastic drugs, or immunosuppressive drugs

facility.name: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

responsible_party.organization: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

group.title: Rate of Wound Closure Collagenase Santyl vs. Vehicle
group.description: Dermatome-induced skin wounds treated with drug active (collagenase). Each subject received 2 identical wounds, one on each arm. One arm was treated with Collagenase Santyl, the other with Vehicle. Each subject acted as their own control.

group.title: Rate of Wound Closure Collagenase Santyl vs. Vehicle
group.description: Dermatome-induced skin wounds treated with drug active (collagenase). Each subject received 2 identical wounds, one on each arm. One arm was treated with Collagenase Santyl, the other with Vehicle. Each subject acted as their own control.

outcome.title: Time to Complete Wound Closure Collagenase Santyl and Vehicle
outcome.population: Analysis was performed on all subjects as intent-to-treat (ITT).

group.title: Collagenase Santyl Rate of Wound Closure
group.description: Dermatome-induced skin wounds treated with drug active (collagenase). Each subject received 2 identical wounds, one on each arm. One arm was treated with Collagenase Santyl, the other with Vehicle. Each subject acted as their own control.

group.title: Vehicle Rate to Complete Wound Healing
group.description: Dermatome-induced skin wounds treated with Vehicle alone. Each subject received 2 identical wounds, one on each arm. One arm was treated with Collagenase Santyl, the other with Vehicle. Each subject acted as their own control.

measure.title: Time to Complete Wound Closure Collagenase Santyl and Vehicle
measure.population: Analysis was performed on all subjects as intent-to-treat (ITT).

analysis.groups_desc: Each subject served as their own control, each receiving duplicate dermatome-induced wounds with 1 wound treated with active drug and the other treated with vehicle. Mean time to wound closure was calculated for the wounds treated with drug, the wounds treated with vehicle, and an over-all mean time to wound closure
analysis.method_desc: Time to complete wound closure Drug(T1)and Vehicle(T2)Hypothesis, Ho: T1=T2,using paired Prentice-Wilcoxon at significant level of 5%, 2-sided.

outcome.title: Differences in Scar Viscoelasticity Between Wounds Treated With Collagenase Santyl and Its Vehicle
outcome.description: Differences in Scar Viscoelasticity between wounds treated with Collagenase Santyl and its vehicle as measured by Stiffness and Energy Absorption using BTC-2000 measurements.

group.title: Collagenase Santyl Rate of Wound Closure
group.description: Dermatome-induced skin wounds treated with drug active (collagenase). Each subject received 2 identical wounds, one on each arm. One arm was treated with Collagenase Santyl, the other with Vehicle. Each subject acted as their own control.

group.title: Vehicle Rate of Wound Closure
group.description: Dermatome-induced skin wounds treated with Vehicle alone. Each subject received 2 identical wounds, one on each arm. One arm was treated with Collagenase Santyl, the other with Vehicle. Each subject acted as their own control.

measure.title: Differences in Scar Viscoelasticity Between Wounds Treated With Collagenase Santyl and Its Vehicle
measure.description: Differences in Scar Viscoelasticity between wounds treated with Collagenase Santyl and its vehicle as measured by Stiffness and Energy Absorption using BTC-2000 measurements.

analysis.groups_desc: Stiffness: Paired t-test and Wilcoxon signed rank test were used for testing any significant differences (Sig. diff.) between the two treatments
Energy Absorption: Paired t-test and Wilcoxon signed rank test were used for testing any significant differences (Sig. diff.) between the two treatments

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse event data was collected over the 9 month period of the study
reported_events.desc: Adverse events were captured, but the Investigator did not always capture which arm exhibited the adverse event, so no in depth analysis could be performed. Of the 2 subjects whose adverse event was probably related to test article (as designated by the Investigator), only 1 had the arm designated and that arm was treated with vehicle.

group.title: Rate of Wound Closure Collagenase Santyl vs. Vehicle
group.description: Dermatome-induced skin wounds treated with drug active (collagenase). Each subject received 2 identical wounds, one on each arm. One arm was treated with Collagenase Santyl, the other with Vehicle. Each subject acted as their own control.

event.description: The 1 SAE (brain aneurysm) was reported as severe and was unrelated to the test articles

Wound redness (erythema)- Investigator specified Right Arm for 1 subject, which was treated with Vehicle. Investigator did not specify arm for the second subject with erythema, so causative agent could not be determined.

For 1 subject the Investigator did not specify which arm developed the rash, so unable to determine if Collagenase Santyl or its vehicle was causative agent. For the other subject the Investigator specified that both arms developed a rash.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
